subject: history
title: Administrative Reforms (1858-1885)
description: Major administrative and constitutional reforms following the 1857 revolt

events.title: Government of India Act, 1858
events.description: End of Company rule, Crown takes control

points: Passed on 2 August 1858 by British Parliament
East India Company abolished as ruling power
Queen Victoria became sovereign of India
Secretary of State for India created (member of British Cabinet)
15-member Council of India to assist Secretary
details.significance: Fundamental restructuring - marked beginning of British Raj

points: Treaty obligations with princes to be respected
Equal treatment under law regardless of race/religion
Indians to be freely admitted to government offices
details.significance: Set policy framework for Crown administration

points: Viceroy's Executive Council expanded for legislative purposes
Portfolio system introduced in Executive Council
Provincial legislative councils created (Bengal, Madras, Bombay)
Power to make laws for peace and good governance
details.significance: Beginning of legislative process in India; very limited Indian participation

points: Main purpose: law and order, protect British rule
Indians in lower ranks, British in higher positions
details.significance: Created police structure that continues with modifications today

points: High Courts established at Calcutta, Bombay, Madras (1862)
Replaced Supreme Courts and Sadar Courts
Crown law and Company's regulations unified
English became court language at higher levels
details.significance: Unified judicial system; foundation of modern Indian judiciary

points: Certain expenditure heads transferred to provinces
Provinces could impose taxes on specific items
Viceroy Lord Mayo extended financial powers
Provincial governments made responsible for specific services
Given fixed grants and power to tax
Police, jails, education, medical services provincialised

events.title: Statutory Civil Service
events.description: Attempt at Indianization of civil service

points: Created to recruit Indians without examination
Could nominate Indians to covenanted posts
But very few Indians actually recruited
Strong opposition from existing British officers
details.significance: Tokenism; failed to achieve real Indianization

events.title: Vernacular Press Act
events.description: Repressive law to control Indian newspapers

details.significance: Showed British fear of growing nationalist press; united Indians against repression

points: Indians required license to possess arms
After 1857, British didn't trust Indians with weapons
Hurt Indian pride and sense of masculinity
details.significance: Humiliating law showing British distrust of Indians

points: Local boards for district and municipal administration
Powers over local taxation, education, health, roads
details.significance: Beginning of democratic institutions; training for future self-governance

events.title: Ilbert Bill Controversy
events.description: Attempt to remove racial discrimination in judiciary

points: Proposed by Viceroy Ripon and Law Member C.P. Ilbert
Would allow Indian judges to try European defendants
Europeans united to oppose the bill
Jury with European majority made mandatory
Exposed racist attitudes of British community
details.significance: Awakened Indians to racial discrimination; promoted national consciousness

points: Senate made smaller, official element increased
details.significance: Attempt to control growing educated middle class
